Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Molecular Understanding of Atmospheric Nucleation: Reactions of Amines with Sulfuric Acid Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Several new instruments will be used to explore the hypothesis that the high aerosol nucleation rates observed in the atmospheric boundary layer are primarily due to the reaction of amines with sulfuric acid molecular clusters. The cluster chemical ionization mass spectrometer (Cluster CIMS) measures the concentrations and masses of neutral molecular clusters produced by nucleation. The diethylene glycol condensation particle counter (DEG CPC), when used as the detector for an aerosol mobility spectrometer, allows measurements of particle mobility distributions down to 1 nanometer size. Parallel measurements with the Cluster CIMS allow definition of the complete spectrum of sizes down to one molecule. The ambient pressure proton transfer mass spectrometer (AmpMS) allows real-time measurements of amines. Computational chemistry will complement laboratory nucleation experiments and measurements in the atmosphere of Pittsburgh, PA by helping to elucidate processes that occur during chemical ionization in the Cluster CIMS as well as the thermodynamic and kinetic processes responsible for the formation of stable nuclei in the atmosphere.

The formation of new particles by nucleation in the atmosphere affects concentrations of cloud nuclei and, therefore, the earth's albedo. Uncertainties in the cloud albedo effect are the largest source of uncertainty in climate models. Accounting for new particle production is one source of this uncertainty. This project will support two graduate students and a post-doctoral scholar as well as offer research experience opportunities to undergraduate students. Outreach activities will include presentations to and laboratory exercises with Minnesota school students, involvement in science camp efforts in collaboration with the Department of Chemistry's chapter of Women in Science and Engineering, and efforts to increase awareness of the health impacts of wood smoke emissions from cook stoves in developing countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Airborne particles (aerosol particles) are ubiquitous in the atmosphere. Particles serve as cloud condensation nuclei; without particles, there would be no clouds, and without clouds, there would be no rain. Photographic images of the earth taken from satellites show that, at any given time, clouds cover a substantial fraction of the earth's surface. Because clouds are bright, they decrease the amount of solar radiation that warms the earth. In cloud-free regions, aerosol particles both scatter and absorb the sun's radiation, so cloud-free aerosols can lead to either cooling or warming. Thus, aerosol particles regulate the earth's hydrologic cycle and affect its radiation balance.

Atmospheric particles originate from diverse sources, including combustion smoke, sea spray, wind-blown dust, pollen, etc. About one half of them (by number) are born in the atmosphere by a process referred to as homogeneous nucleation. Homogeneous nucleation occurs when gases combine to form stable molecular clusters that ultimately grow to sizes that are large enough to affect cloud formation or radiation. The research supported by this NSF proposal focused on studying the physical and chemical processes by which trace atmospheric constituents nucleate to form stable molecular clusters.

Our laboratory and field research uses prototype instruments that we've designed and built. These measurements are inherently uncertain, as they are affected by imperfectly understood physical and chemical processes. One of these instruments, the Cluster Chemical Ionization Mass Spectrometer (Cluster CIMS), measures the concentrations of sulfuric acid vapor and molecular clusters that it forms. Another instrument, the diethylene glycol scanning mobility particle spectrometer (DEG SMPS), measure aerosol number distributions down to the  ~1 nm geometric diameter. We developed a novel approach to compare measurements from these instruments in the ~1 nm range where they overlap and found reasonable agreement. This allowed us establish realistic estimates of measurement uncertainty.

Our research team carried out atmospheric measurements between 1991-1995 showing that nucleation rates (i.e., rates of stable particle production) are well correlated with concentrations of sulfuric acid vapor. This demonstrated that sulfuric acid is likely a participant in nucleation. However, the results were also puzzling because the established theory at that time predicted that sulfuric acid was too volatile to nucleate at a significant rate. In 1995 we observed a burst of particle formation downwind of Macquarie Island in the Southern Ocean. Macquarie Island is a penguin rookery, and we speculated that "additional trace gas species (e.g., ammonia) reduce the vapor pressures of the participating species, thereby permitting nucleation to occur at much lower sulfuric acid partial pressures". 1 This NSF proposal focused on identifying compounds that react with sulfuric acid to enhance nucleation rates, and on quantifying their effects.

In recent years, work by several groups including ours has shown ammonia plus sulfuric acid leads to substantially higher nucleation rates than sulfuric acid alone. However, ammonia cannot explain the high nucleation rates that are observed in the atmosphere. Nucleation researchers have recently focused on amines and highly oxidized organic compounds as being primarily responsible for the high nucleation rates that are observed. Laboratory measurements have shown that these compounds are far more effective than ammonia.
